title: Malariaverse Workshop
text:
‚òï Coffee break activity ‚òï
On your table you should find post-it notes, pens and dot stickers. During the coffee/lunch breaks and throughout the day please:

On post-it notes, write down ideas for how to improve the malariaverse:


New features
Additional packages
Improvements to current packages
Ways to maximise academic impact
Ways to maximise access/use


Stick your ideas where you think they lie on the Effort vs Impact plane on the board
Up-vote the ideas of others with a dot sticker






There will be time at the end of the day to review and discuss suggestions

title: Malariaverse Workshop
text: An interactive workshop to provide an overview of how to use üì¶ [malariasimulation] and the malariaverse to run context-specific simulations for a country or region.

title: Malariaverse Workshop
text:
Workshop details
üóìÔ∏è Thursday 2nd February 2023
‚è∞ 0930-1700
üè® Meeting room 1&2, 20 Eastbourne Terrace, Paddington
üíª Please bring your laptop!

title: Malariaverse Workshop
text:
Before the workshop
Please make sure you have the following installed:

An up-to-date (Version >=4.2.0) installation of R. Please note, for those updating to R version 4.2 and above who have not updated recently you may also require an updated version of Rtools.
An up-to-date (Version >= 2022.12.0) installation of RStudio. See help->check for updates.
üì¶ [malariasimulation]
The workshop üì¶ [mvw]
The malariaverse üì¶ [foresite]

When installing packages please say ‚Äúyes‚Äù to any prompts asking you to update or install dependencies.

# For malariasimulation
options(repos = c(
    mrcide = "https://mrc-ide.r-universe.dev",
    CRAN = "https://cloud.r-project.org"))
install.packages("malariasimulation") # v1.4.3

# The workshop package (and its dependencies) can be installed directly from github:
remotes::install_github("mrc-ide/mvw")  # v0.1.2

# Private packages require network access to the "malaria drive": \\fi--didef3.dide.ic.ac.uk/malaria. 
# Contact Pete if you don't have access.
drat::addRepo("malariaverse", "file:\\\\projects.dide.ic.ac.uk/malaria/malariaverse/drat")
install.packages("foresite", type = "source") # v0.1.0

Following installation you should be able to successfully run:

output <- malariasimulation::run_simulation(100)
output

and

mvw::run_tutorial("Test")

If you can‚Äôt, please contact Pete before the workshop, by 30/01/2023 latest.

title: Bednet
text:
For each aspect of net distribution, state if the average population usage will increase or decrease:


Quiz

title: Bednet
text:
Fitting malariasimulation inputs
Consider the following scenario:

Time period: 10 years (time units are days so, for year one: t = 1:365)
Bed net usage estimates of 12%, 18%, 45%, 50% and 40%, collected at the mid point of the year (1st June) in years 1, 3, 5, 7, and 9
Known mass net distributions at the start of the year (1st January) in years 1, 2, 4, 7 and 8.
Net retention half life of 5 years

Using these estimates and the netz::fit_usage() function, in the code box below estimate the model input distribution to achieve the observed bed net usage over time.


library(netz)





library(netz)
year <- 365
timesteps <- 10 * year
net_hl <- 5 * year

# Target usage associated time points
target <- c(0.12, 0.18, 0.45, 0.50, 0.40)
target_tt <- floor((c(1, 3, 5, 7, 9) - 0.5) * year)
# Time points at which distribution will occur
distribution_tt <- 1 + c(0, 1, 3, 6, 7) * year

# Fit
fit <- netz::fit_usage(
  target_usage = target,
  target_usage_timesteps = target_tt,
  distribution_timesteps = distribution_tt + 1
)

round(fit$par, 2)


With your estimated inputs and the netz::population_usage() function, plot the estimated usage over time alongside the usage observations.


library(netz)





library(netz)

# Our estimates of the distributions
fitted_input <- c(0.13, 0.15, 0.53, 0.33, 0.16)

year <- 365
timesteps <- 10 * year
net_hl <- 5 * year

# Target usage associated time points
target <- c(0.12, 0.18, 0.45, 0.50, 0.40)
target_tt <- floor((c(1, 3, 5, 7, 9) - 0.5) * year)
# Time points at which distribution will occur
distribution_tt <- 1 + c(0, 1, 3, 6, 7) * year
# Estimate population usage over time
pu <- population_usage(
  timesteps = timesteps,
  distribution = fitted_input,
  distribution_timesteps = distribution_tt,
  half_life = net_hl)
# Plot the results against the target
plot(1:timesteps, pu, t = "l", ylim = c(0, 0.8), ylab = "Population usage", xlab = "Time")
points(target ~ target_tt, col = "dodgerblue", pch = 19)


‚ùì Are they a good match?
Extra credits ‚ú®:

Examine the distribution_upper argument of netz::fit_usage(). How does the fit look if you limit the maximum a single distribution can be to 40% of the population?
We may be uncertain about the net distribution dates. Do other sets of distribution dates also allow a good fit to the observed bed net usage estimates?

title: Bednet
text:
Working with country net data
When working with country net data there are various bed net metrics that you might encounter.
Match the following definitions and metrics:


Quiz










































Using the netz::usage_rate(), netz::access_to_usage() and netz::usage_to_access() functions, use the code box below to generate answers to the following questions


library(netz)





Quiz
































Can you work out the annual cost for the following scenario:

Annual distributions
Cost per net delivered of $5
Population size of 10,000
Net loss half life of 2.5 years, net loss retention function: net_loss_map()
Usage of 70% and usage rate of 0.8

The netz flow diagram might help


library(netz)





library(netz)
population <- 10000
cost_per_net_delivered <- 5
year <- 365
distribution_freq <- 1 * year
retention_half_life <- 2.5 * year
net_loss_function <- net_loss_map
usage <- 0.7
usage_rate <- 0.8

# Now use the netz conversion functions to translate
# usage -> access -> crop -> distribution




library(netz)
population <- 10000
cost_per_net_delivered <- 5
year <- 365
distribution_freq <- 1 * year
retention_half_life <- 2.5 * year
net_loss_function <- net_loss_map
usage <- 0.7
usage_rate <- 0.8

access <- netz::usage_to_access(usage, usage_rate)
crop <- netz::access_to_crop(access)
nets_distributed_per_capita <- netz::crop_to_distribution(crop, distribution_freq, retention_half_life, net_loss_function)
nets_distributed <- nets_distributed_per_capita * population
cost <- nets_distributed * cost_per_net_delivered
cost

title: Calibration
text:
Let‚Äôs start with a quiz to explore possible situations where you might face the decision of whether to calibrate or not


Quiz

title: Calibration
text:
The summary function
When running calibrate() we must provide a summary function that summarised the raw simulation output in the same format as our target. For example, if our target data is a vector of annual PfPr2-10 estimates of length 5, then our summary function must take the raw simulation output and return a vector of annual PfPr2-10 estimates of length 5.

In the code box below, complete the summary function, to match the format of our target data. The output of the function should be three values for the all age clinical incidence (cases per person per year) in simulation years 2, 3 and 4.



# Target: all age clinical incidence (cases per person per year) in years 2, 3 and 4
target <- c(0.03, 0.02, 0.01)
# Raw simulation output
simulation <- data.frame(
  timestep = 1:(365 * 5),
  n = 10000,
  cases = rpois(365 * 5, 200 / 365)
)
# Summary function
summary_function <- function(simulation){
  
}
summary_function(simulation)





# Summary function - estimate annual incidence in years 2-4
summary_function <- function(simulation){
  year <- ceiling(simulation$timestep / 365)
  annual_inc <- tapply(simulation$cases, year, sum) / 10000
  return(annual_inc[2:4])
}

title: Calibration
text:
Calibrate good times, come on üéâ
In the following code box we can run a simple calibration.

Work through the code in the box to make sure you understand what each section is doing.
When you‚Äôre happy hit run to perform the calibration. Remember, calibration takes multiple model-runs so won‚Äôt be instant (this example is artificially set up to run reasonably quickly).

After the calibration finishes you‚Äôll see a print out summarising the attempted EIR and comparisons between the summarised model output and target.


library(malariasimulation)
library(cali)

# Define our target. In this example we have a PfPr estimate for year 3
target_pfpr <- 0.3

# Define our simulation parameters, we need to add $timesteps for the calibration
p <- malariasimulation::get_parameters(
  overrides = list(
    human_population = 5000,
    individual_mosquitoes = FALSE
  )
)
p$timesteps <- 3 * 365

# Write our summary function. To match the target we need to
# output average PfPr in year 3
get_pfpr_year_3 <- function(simulation_output){
  year3 <- simulation_output[simulation_output$timestep > 2 * 365,]
  pfpr <- year3$n_detect_730_3650 / year3$n_730_3650
  average_pfpr <- mean(pfpr)
  return(average_pfpr)
}

# Run a test simulation to check our target function does what it should!
simulation <- malariasimulation::run_simulation(
  timesteps = p$timesteps,
  parameters = p
)
# Does this look right? Does it match the type of target data?
get_pfpr_year_3(simulation)

# When we are happy we can run the calibration
set.seed(1234)
calibration <- cali::calibrate(target = target_pfpr,
                summary_function = get_pfpr_year_3,
                parameters = p,
                tolerance = 0.005,
                low = 1, high = 10)

message("Calibrated EIR estimate: ", calibration)



Lets check our results, in the code box below:

Use the estimated, calibrated EIR from above to modify our parameter inputs
Plot simulated PfPr over time
Add your target.

‚ùì Do they match?


target_pfpr <- 0.3

# Set the initial parameters
calibrated_p <- malariasimulation::get_parameters(
  overrides = list(
    human_population = 5000,
    individual_mosquitoes = FALSE
  )
)
calibrated_p$timesteps <- 3 * 365

# Set the initial EIR (!!! Add your calibrated estimate here !!!)
calibrated_p <- calibrated_p |>
  malariasimulation::set_equilibrium(init_EIR = )

set.seed(1234)
calibrated_simulation <- malariasimulation::run_simulation(
  timesteps = calibrated_p$timesteps,
  parameters = calibrated_p
)





# Set the initial EIR (Add your calibrated estimate here)
calibrated_p <- calibrated_p |>
  malariasimulation::set_equilibrium(init_EIR = 4.216965)

# Plotting output
calibrated_prev <- calibrated_simulation$n_detect_730_3650 / calibrated_simulation$n_730_3650
year <- calibrated_simulation$timestep / 365

plot(NA, xlim = c(0, 3), ylim = c(0, 0.8),
     xlab = "Year", ylab = "PfPr")
segments(x0 = 2, y0 = target_pfpr, x1 = 3, y1 = target_pfpr, col = "red", lwd = 4)
lines(calibrated_prev ~ year)


Extra credits ‚ú®:

Modify the calibration code to calibrate to 3 years of target data.
Read about the weights argument in ?calibrate(), have a go a weighting your target data so more recent years are more influential.
What happens if you change the tolerance argument in ?calibrate()

title: Introduction
text:
Let‚Äôs start by getting better acquainted with a country site file. In the code box below we have pre-loaded the site for Togo (iso3c = TGO).
Use the interactive code box below to explore the elements that make up the site file.

Choose to explore specific elements of a list with the $ operator. For example togo_site_file$seasonality or togo_site_file$prevalence . You can see all the elements with names(togo_site_file). It may be helpful to plot some elements to see what is going on.
Dig into the togo_site_file details to answer the questions below. Remember, you can find out more information about site file elements on the foresite website.



library(foresite)
togo_site_file <- TGO





Quiz

title: Introduction
text:
Extracting a single site
Each country site file contains multiple sites. In our case these are sub-national units where the population is further disaggregated spatially and by the urban/rural distinction. We can use the helper function site::single_site() to extract information for a single site (sub-national unit) from the country site file.
To find out which site to index we can look up all of the sites within a country with $sites.
By editing the code below:

Isolate the site iso3c = TGO, name_1 = Savanes urban_rural = rural
Plot the estimated bed net usage for that site over time
Examine your plot to answer the question below



library(foresite)
library(site)
togo_site_file <- TGO





library(foresite)
library(site)
togo_site_file <- TGO
togo_site_file$sites
savanes_rural <- single_site(togo_site_file, 9)
plot(savanes_rural$interventions$itn_use ~ savanes_rural$interventions$year, t = "l")




Quiz

title: Introduction
text:
Running a single site
Now lets try running a site.

Use the site::single_site() function to isolate the site for: Run iso3c = TGO, name_1 = Plateaux, urban_rural = rural.
Create a üì¶ malariasimulation parameter list using the site::site_parameters() function. For today, in the overrides argument you might want to set a reasonably small population so that the model runs quickly, for example overrides  = list(human_population = 5000).
Run the site using malariasimulation::run_simulation()
Plot the PfPr2-10 estimated by the model (hint: the output n_detect_ is the number positive and n_ the number of individuals in a given age group).
Overlay the Malaria Atlas Project estimates of PfPr2-10 onto your plot (see $prevalence).

‚ö†Ô∏è The model run may take a little while to complete (~5 mins). While you wait, why not have a look at the foresite website, or starting thinking through the coffee break activity ‚ö†Ô∏è


library(foresite)
library(site)
library(malariasimulation)
togo_site_file <- TGO





library(foresite)
library(site)
library(malariasimulation)
togo_site_file <- TGO
# Isolate the site
site_index <- which(togo_site_file$sites$name_1 == "Plateaux" &
                      togo_site_file$sites$urban_rural == "rural")
plateaux_rural <- single_site(togo_site_file, site_index)
# Create parameter inputs
site_pars <- site_parameters(
  interventions = plateaux_rural$interventions,
  demography = plateaux_rural$demography,
  vectors = plateaux_rural$vectors,
  seasonality = plateaux_rural$seasonality,
  eir = plateaux_rural$eir$eir[1],
  overrides = list(human_population = 5000)
)
# Run!
model_run <- run_simulation(timesteps = site_pars$timesteps,
                            parameters = site_pars)
# Calculate prevalence
model_run$prevalence <- model_run$n_detect_730_3649 / model_run$n_730_3649
# Set the time
model_run$t <- (model_run$timestep / 365) + 2000
# Plot
plot(model_run$prevalence ~ model_run$t, t = "l", ylim = c(0, 0.8), xlab = "Year", ylab = "Prevalence")
# Add MAP prevalence
points(plateaux_rural$prevalence$year + 0.5, plateaux_rural$prevalence$pfpr, pch = 19, col = "darkred")


‚ùì How well do they match?
‚ùì Why might there be differences between modelled PfPr2-10 and the estimates from the Malaria Atlas Project?
Extra credits ‚ú®:

Try changing the EIR argument in site_parameters() and re-running.
Modify plateaux_rural$interventions$irs_cov and re-run, can you see the impact?
Try running multiple different sites and estimating aggregated PfPr2-10 across all of them.

Bed nets

Feedback & Discussion




Workshop practicals are included as part of the üì¶ [mvw]. They can be accessed using the run_tutorial() function.

mvw::run_tutorial("Introduction")
mvw::run_tutorial("Calibration")
mvw::run_tutorial("Bednet")

title: Malariaverse Workshop Introduction
text:
Welcome all!
Today‚Äôs aims:

Provide a broad overview of context-specific modelling
Site files: how to characterise a setting
Introduce the malariaverse packages to support üì¶[malariasimulation] modelling
Exercises:

Running a site
Calibrating a site
Dealing with bed nets

title: Malariaverse Workshop Introduction
text:
Not today‚Äôs aims üòÑ

An introduction to the Imperial college malaria model

Please see key publications

An introduction to the software packages implementing the model

üì¶[malariasimulation]
üì¶[]
Please see websites and supporting documentation for help

A comprehensive overview of all malariaverse packages/features


https://mrc-ide.github.io/malariasimulation https://mrc-ide.github.io/deterministic model..

title: Malariaverse Workshop Introduction
text: Thanks üíñ

title: Malariaverse Workshop Introduction
text:
Modelling philosophy
One common dichotomisation is between:

Generic modelling

Run the model for generic settings (e.g.¬†Low/Medium/High PfPr2-10)
Allows precise exploration of model behaviour and intervention impact in controlled in silico environment
Can be challenging to translate general results
e.g.¬†Modelling population-level impact to inform target product profiles for childhood malaria vaccines. Hogan et al BMC Medicine, 2018.

title: Malariaverse Workshop Introduction
text:
Modelling philosophy
One common dichotomisation is between:

Context-specific modelling

Run the model for a specific setting/location
Can be used to inform policy and impact assessment for specific areas
Requires ‚Äúthe context‚Äù to be adequately captured ü§î
e.g.¬†Estimated impact of RTS,S/AS01 malaria vaccine allocation strategies in sub-Saharan Africa: A modelling study Hogan et al PLoS Medicine, 2020.

title: Malariaverse Workshop Introduction
text: How do we characterise a setting?

title: Malariaverse Workshop Introduction
text:
Important features

Intrinsic transmission potential (‚ÄúBaseline‚Äù, ‚ÄúCarrying capacity‚Äù, ‚ÄúR0‚Äù)
The mosquito vector

species
bionomics (how the ü¶ü relates to its environment) & behaviour
distribution & relative abundance
insecticide resistance

Rainfall seasonality ‚òî
Historical interventions
Epidemiological data (e.g.¬†PfPr2-10, malaria cases)
Human population & demography üßë‚Äçü§ù‚Äçüßë

title: Malariaverse Workshop Introduction
text:
Key data sources

For many of these elements there are data available, for example:

World Malaria Report
Malaria Atlas project (burden and intervention coverage estimates)
Vector Atlas (spatial vector data, under development and building on work by Sinka et al)

title: Malariaverse Workshop Introduction
text:
Site files

Historically, the group has collected the required information to characterise a setting into a ‚ÄúSite file‚Äù.
We have tried to formalise this approach in malariaverse
The üì¶[foresite] package contains our first-pass attempt at site-files for all countries
They contains estimates for all of the important features needed to characterise a site
The foresite website contains detailed information about each element of a site file


https://mrc-ide.github.io/foresite

title: Malariaverse Workshop Introduction
text:
Site files

Site files in üì¶[foresite] are defined at the first administrative unit level and further disaggregated between urban and rural populations

title: Malariaverse Workshop Introduction
text:
Site files

We can view all the sites associated with a country site-file in üì¶[foresite]


library(foresite)
TGO$sites

   country iso3c   name_1 urban_rural
1     Togo   TGO   Centre       rural
2     Togo   TGO   Centre       urban
3     Togo   TGO     Kara       rural
4     Togo   TGO     Kara       urban
5     Togo   TGO Maritime       rural
6     Togo   TGO Maritime       urban
7     Togo   TGO Plateaux       rural
8     Togo   TGO Plateaux       urban
9     Togo   TGO  Savanes       rural
10    Togo   TGO  Savanes       urban

text:
Site files

library(foresite)

title: Malariaverse Workshop Introduction
text:
Using site files

The site files in üì¶[foresite] are a general attempt to collate information for all malaria-endemic settings
They are, at best, a coarse representation of the true picture
Please always consider your use-case carefully ü§î, it is likely you may

Have direct or be working with people with direct knowledge of a setting
Have more location specific data
Have more up to date data
Want to model at a different spatial scale

The Malariaverse aims to provide you with the tools to be able to make necessary improvements to site files and construct new ones from scratch üõ†Ô∏è

title: Malariaverse Workshop Introduction
text:
Running a site

We can use another malariaverse üì¶[site] to translate the site file information into üì¶[malariasimulation] parameter input.


# Isolate a single site from a country
example_site <- site::single_site(foresite::TGO, 1)
# Create parameter inputs
site_pars <- site::site_parameters(
  interventions = example_site$interventions,
  demography = example_site$demography,
  vectors = example_site$vectors,
  seasonality = example_site$seasonality,
  eir = example_site$eir$eir[1],
  overrides = list(human_population = 10000)
)
# Run!
model_run <- malariasimulation::run_simulation(timesteps = site_pars$timesteps,
                                               parameters = site_pars)

title: Malariaverse Workshop Introduction
text:
Let‚Äôs give it a try!

üì¶ [mvw] has interactive tutorials. You can run code within the tutorial window (or in R/Rstudio if desired).
Run mvw::run_tutorial("Introduction")

title: Malariaverse Workshop Calibration
text:
Welcome back!
Session aims:

Understand why we need to ‚Äúcalibrate‚Äù a site
Understand when we need to calibrate/re-calibrate
Introduction to üì¶[cali] for model calibration
Common challenges/issues when calibrating

title: Malariaverse Workshop Calibration
text:
Why calibrate

Given all the information about a site (vectors, season PfPr2-10 etc‚Ä¶). We still need to make our best estimation of the ‚Äúbaseline‚Äù level of transmission.
One relatively simple way of doing this is by modifying the modelled baseline until our model output best matches some observations (e.g.¬†PfPr2-10).

title: Malariaverse Workshop Calibration
text: Calibration process

title: Malariaverse Workshop Calibration
text: Calibration process

title: Malariaverse Workshop Calibration
text: Calibration process

title: Malariaverse Workshop Calibration
text:
Calibration note

Warmup üí™

üì¶ malariasimulation runs do not automatically run a warmup period which is necessary for the model to fully equilibrate. In general it is always advisable to add a warmup period to your simulation runs. Some outputs are more sensitive than others and exploration of a suitable warmup period to use should be performed prior to calibration.
Subsequent model runs after calibration should use the same warmup period as the calibration.

Data üìë

It will be your decision on what data (and how much of it) to calibrate to
It is important to understand how and when data were collected, for example data collected at peak malaria season may look very different to that collected in the low season.

title: Malariaverse Workshop Calibration
text:
When to calibrate

Calibration or re-calibration is not always required. In general, you will need to calibrate if:


You have created a new site file
You have modified any site inputs that occur before or at the same time as the data you are trying to calibrate to
The data you are calibrating to has changed
There has been a change to an underlying assumption that would impact the disease dynamics in a model run

title: Malariaverse Workshop Calibration
text:
Foresite calibrations

Site files in üì¶ [foresite] have been calibrated $eir

title: Malariaverse Workshop Calibration
text:
Cali

We can use üì¶cali for model calibration.
The calibrate() function takes a target, for example annual PfPr2-10 for the years 2015-2020.
The user defines a summary_function, a function that takes the raw model output and produces the model estimate corresponding to the target. In this case our summary function will summarise the model-estimated PfPr2-10 for the years 2015-2020
calibrate() will then search a range of EIRs until the outputs of summary_function and within a user-defined tolerance of the target

title: Malariaverse Workshop Calibration
text:
Cali

It is always good practice to run a simulation and test your summary_function before using it in calibrate() - this will help with debugging üêû.
There a lots of other tuning and model options, so please see ?calibrate() for more detailed information.

title: Malariaverse Workshop Calibration
text:
Challenges

üì¶cali is (hopefully) convenient, however it doesn‚Äôt remove the need to run the model multiple time when calibrating. Therefore be prepared for the process to be lengthy, often requiring calibration runs to be performed on the high performance cluster.

title: Malariaverse Workshop Calibration
text:
Challenges

Available data and model outputs are not guaranteed to play nicely

title: Malariaverse Workshop Calibration
text:
Challenges
Sometimes calibration can look good:

title: Malariaverse Workshop Calibration
text:
Challenges
‚Ä¶and sometimes not üò¢ :

title: Malariaverse Workshop Calibration
text:
Challenges

Calibration can be difficult when results are dominated by stochasticity:

low transmission
small populations
calibrating to a sub-group in the population
etc‚Ä¶

title: Malariaverse Workshop Calibration
text:
Let‚Äôs give it a try!

Run mvw::run_tutorial("Calibration")

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
text:
Session 3 üí™!
Session aims:

Understand why bed nets can be challenging to model
Overview of bed net metrics and model inputs
Using üì¶ [netz] to traverse the bed net landscape
Implementing bed nets in üì¶ [malariasimulation]

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
section: Why can bed nets be tricky?
text:
Why can bed nets be tricky?

The effective coverage of bed nets today depends on the cumulative impacts of net distributions and net loss over many prior years.

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
section: Why can bed nets be tricky?
text:
Why can bed nets be tricky?

There are lots of bed net metrics:

Delivery to country
Distribution within country
Crop (total number of nets within a country)
Access and usage

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
section: Why can bed nets be tricky?
text:
Why can bed nets be tricky?

‚Ä¶ and lots of other bed net variables to consider:

Net type
Net retention (or rate of loss)
Distribution method/schedule (mass, routine etc.)
Interaction with insecticide resistance

And finally, how we implement bed nets in üì¶ [malariasimulation]

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
section: An empirical model of bed nets
text:
An empirical model of bed nets

Amelia Bertozzi-Villa et al have published a model linking bed net metrics for countries in SSA1.
We can use this model to translate between the different bed net metrics
The model includes country-level fits




Bertozzi-Villa et al., ‚ÄòMaps and Metrics of Insecticide-Treated Net Access, Use, and Nets-per-Capita in Africa from 2000-2020‚Äô. Nat Comms (2021).

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
section: An empirical model of bed nets
text:
An empirical model of bed nets



The model triangulates net deliveries to a country with information on distributions and survey data on access and usage.












Bertozzi-Villa et al., ‚ÄòMaps and Metrics of Insecticide-Treated Net Access, Use, and Nets-per-Capita in Africa from 2000-2020‚Äô. Nat Comms (2021).

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
section: An empirical model of bed nets
text:
An empirical model of bed nets



The model also estimates country-specific net retention times












Bertozzi-Villa et al., ‚ÄòMaps and Metrics of Insecticide-Treated Net Access, Use, and Nets-per-Capita in Africa from 2000-2020‚Äô. Nat Comms (2021).

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
section: An empirical model of bed nets
text:
An empirical model of bed nets



Bertozzi-Villa et al show that access and crop are not linearly related (at the country level).
This can have big implications when costing a bet net campaign.












Bertozzi-Villa et al., ‚ÄòMaps and Metrics of Insecticide-Treated Net Access, Use, and Nets-per-Capita in Africa from 2000-2020‚Äô. Nat Comms (2021).

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
text:
üì¶ [netz]

The üì¶ [netz] has translated some of the work by Bertozzi-Villa et al.
It can facilitate translation between different bed net metrics.
It can be used to access country-specific data.
It also has functionality for specifying bed nets in üì¶ [malariasimulation]

üôè Big thank you to Nora for lots of hard work on üì¶ [netz]!

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
text: Schematic overview

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
text:
Usage and Access

Usage: the proportion of people who have slept under a bed net the previous night. This is effective coverage.
Access: the proportion of the population that could sleep under a net.
üì¶ [netz] has functions to convert between usage and access:

netz::usage_to_access(usage = 0.5, use_rate = 0.8)
netz::access_to_usage(access = 0.5, use_rate = 0.8)

You can view empirical estimates of country use rates with:

netz::get_usage_rate_data()

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
text:
Access and crop

Access: the proportion of the population that could sleep under a net.
Crop: the total number of nets in the population. Crop increases with net distributions and decreases as nets are worn out and thrown away over time.
üì¶ [netz] has functions to convert between access and crop:

netz::access_to_crop(access = 0.5)
netz::crop_to_access(crop = 0.5)

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
text:
Crop and distributions

Crop: the total number of nets in the population. Crop increases with net distributions and decreases as nets are worn out and thrown away over time.
Distribution: Nets distributed. These may be via mass-distributions or continuous distribution routes.
üì¶ [netz] has functions to convert between crop and distribution:

netz::crop_to_distribution(crop =  0.5, distribution_frequency = 3 * 365, half_life = 2 * 365)
netz::distribution_to_crop(crop =  0.5, distribution_frequency = 3 * 365, half_life = 2 * 365)

Net retention half-lives are estimated in the model by Bertozzi-Villa et al and can be accessed with:

netz::get_halflife_data()

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
text:
Crop and distributions

As crop is the cumulative impact of past distributions, different combinations of past distributions may lead to similar crop estimates. We can dynamically translate between no-equilibrium crop and distributions with:

netz::crop_to_distribution_dynamic(crop = c(0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 0.1), netz::net_loss_map)
netz::distribution_to_crop_dynamic(distribution = c(0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 0.1), netz::net_loss_map)

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
text:
Net loss functions

Net retention can be modelled with different function forms.
In the model by Bertozzi-Villa et al, they use an s-shaped function form.
In üì¶ [malariasimulation] net retention is exponentially distributed.
These are modelled by:

netz::net_loss_map() and netz::net_loss_exp()

These functions can be passed when the argument net_loss_function is required.
We may to try and harmonise the bed net models at some point.

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
text: Schematic overview

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
text:
Implementing bed nets

In üì¶ [malariasimulation] distributions in the model lead directly to effective coverage or usage.
We can use the üì¶ [netz] population_usage() function to view the bed net usage in the model resulting from a given set of bed net distributions (model inputs):


netz::population_usage(
  timesteps = 365 * 30,
  distribution = rep(0.3, 10),
  distribution_timesteps = 365 * seq(1, 30, 3),
  half_life = 365 * 5
)

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
text:
Implementing bed nets

Resulting population usage:

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
text:
Implementing bed nets

More frequent distribution will lead to net usage to build to higher levels:

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
text:
Implementing bed nets

As will larger distributions:

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
text:
Implementing bed nets

We can also model irregular distributions:

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
text:
Fitting bed nets

In many cases we might have a set of observed population level usage estimates that we want to match to. We can use a non-linear optimiser to fit the distribution to these target usages:


# Target usage associated time points
target <- c(0.45, 0.33, 0.7)
target_tt <- c(2, 5, 9) * 365
# Time points at which distribution will occur
distribution_tt <- c(1, 4, 8) * 365

# Fit
fit <- netz::fit_usage(
  target_usage = target,
  target_usage_timesteps = target_tt,
  distribution_timesteps = distribution_tt
)

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
text: Fitting bed nets

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
text: üòµ Conversion overload! üòµ

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
text:
Bed nets in site files

We can look at the bed net inputs in the $interventions section of a site file.
You can see that as well as usage, we have the model input, net type, level of insecticide resistance and associated net efficacy parameters.


head(
  foresite::TGO$interventions[, c("iso3c", "name_1", "urban_rural", "year",
                                "itn_use", "itn_input_dist", "net_type",
                                "pyrethroid_resistance",
                                "dn0", "rn0", "rnm", "gamman")]
  )

  iso3c name_1 urban_rural year    itn_use itn_input_dist        net_type
1   TGO Centre       rural 2000 0.04239319   3.972372e-02 pyrethroid_only
2   TGO Centre       rural 2001 0.03059912   1.999607e-03 pyrethroid_only
3   TGO Centre       rural 2002 0.02194407   1.225237e-05 pyrethroid_only
4   TGO Centre       rural 2003 0.02110716   3.579113e-03 pyrethroid_only
5   TGO Centre       rural 2004 0.14395837   1.402791e-01 pyrethroid_only
6   TGO Centre       rural 2005 0.20412837   9.050257e-02 pyrethroid_only
  pyrethroid_resistance       dn0       rn0  rnm   gamman
1                  0.46 0.2933696 0.6736694 0.24 2.346871
2                  0.48 0.2899376 0.6761727 0.24 2.331779
3                  0.50 0.2869886 0.6783065 0.24 2.317303
4                  0.53 0.2826286 0.6814312 0.24 2.294338
5                  0.55 0.2792447 0.6838313 0.24 2.278917
6                  0.57 0.2763609 0.6858590 0.24 2.262831

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
text:
Bed nets in site files

All of these bed net elements get translated into üì¶ [malariasimulation] parameters when using the üì¶ [site] site_parameters() function.
We also include future resistance extrapolations in the $resistance part of the site file.

üôè No time today to explore all of the amazing work on insecticide resistance and net efficacy, but huge thanks to Tom, Ellie and others for all the hard work!

title: Malariaverse Workshop Bed nets
text:
Let‚Äôs give it a try!

Run mvw::run_tutorial("Bednet")

title: Malariaverse Workshop Lightning round: Umbrella, treasure & om
text:
Session aims:

A whistle-stop tour of some other malariaverse packages
umbrella: for fitting seasonal profiles
treasure: unit costing
om: for (budget-constrained) stratification optimisation

title: Malariaverse Workshop Lightning round: Umbrella, treasure & om
text:
Umbrella

üì¶ [malariasimulation] captures the seasonality in transmission using fourier series parameters fitted to rainfall data.
üì¶ [umbrella] includes some simple functionality to fit these parameters.
üì¶ [umbrella] also has some helper functions to download CHIRPS rainfall ‚Äúdata‚Äù ^1‚Äù.
site_file$seasonality has fitted seasonal parameters for the default sites.




https://www.chc.ucsb.edu/data/chirps

title: Malariaverse Workshop Lightning round: Umbrella, treasure & om
text:
Umbrella workflow

Define your spatial data. This will be spatial polygon(s). I like to use the üì¶ [sf] for spatial data. (I have downloaded and processed sf files associated with all sites: contact me for a link.)
Access satellite rainfall ‚Äúdata‚Äù rasters for the region/period/resolution you require
Extract rainfall data associated with your spatial units
Use umbrella::fit_fourier() to fit parameters that can be used in a site file, or directly in üì¶ [malariasimulation].

title: Malariaverse Workshop Lightning round: Umbrella, treasure & om
text:
Umbrella caveats

Usually use a single, representative seasonal profile for sites.

Needed for forwards projections
May miss inter- and intra-annual variation of interest

The assumption that ‚¨ÜÔ∏è rain = ‚¨ÜÔ∏è mosquitoes = ‚¨ÜÔ∏è malaria does not always hold!

title: Malariaverse Workshop Lightning round: Umbrella, treasure & om
text:
Umbrella info

Check out the umbrella website for more information and a simple introduction vignette.

title: Malariaverse Workshop Lightning round: Umbrella, treasure & om
text:
treasure

üì¶ treasure, is a simple repository for unit costing information that has been used to cost out large global/country scenarios
Mostly serves as a single, version controlled reference for unit costs collected from the literature, WHO and Global Fund.
No time- or country-specific costing information.
If anyone is interested in improving the database, please let me know!

title: Malariaverse Workshop Lightning round: Umbrella, treasure & om
text:
Treasure info

Check out the treasure website for more information.

title: Malariaverse Workshop Lightning round: Umbrella, treasure & om
text:
om

A common challenge is finding the optimum package of interventions across a country, where interventions can be targeted sub-nationally.
Often this question is asked with the additional constraint of a finite budget.
üì¶ om is here to help!

title: Malariaverse Workshop Lightning round: Umbrella, treasure & om
text:
om inputs

üì¶ om requires specific inputs to work:
An impact matrix giving details of the outcome measure we are optimising, for example cases averted. Each row of the matrix is a sub-unit (e.g.¬†district) and each column a unique intervention package.
A cost matrix giving details of the associated cost of each option in the impact matrix
A budget

title: Malariaverse Workshop Lightning round: Umbrella, treasure & om
text:
om and complex budgets

The budget specification in üì¶ om can be simple: e.g.¬†$100
It can also be more complex. For example we might want to optimise the intervention packages across 5 countries, where each country has a domestic budget (to be spent internally) as well as a shared regional budget.

title: Malariaverse Workshop Lightning round: Umbrella, treasure & om
text:
om info

Check out the om website for more information, a simple introduction vignette and a guide for implementing complex budgets.

title: Malariaverse Workshop Feedback & Discussion
section: Preparing for a world post malariaverse workshop ü§©
text:
Preparing for a world post malariaverse workshop ü§©

Encourage people to try out malariaverse packages!
Please do check out the ? help and vignettes.
Issues:

Ask each other.
Post in the malariaverse teams channel (in the DIDE malaria modelling group team).
Submit an issue on the relevant package github page.
Suggest features or fix bugs with a PR request.
